***Footnotes:***

[1](#footnote-anchor-1) I don’t have the percentage figures for the change in sweetshops and clothing stores, I’m sorry.

[2](#footnote-anchor-2) Other blogging platforms are available, including this one, but they’re still *built* for writers; I’m testing the beta of [Nuance](http://nuance.xyz/).

[3](#footnote-anchor-3) Stratechery anticipated this for (cable) TV in [2013](https://stratechery.com/2013/the-jobs-tv-does/#:\~:text=the%20jobs%20tv%20has%20traditionally%20done%20include) and watched it happen in [2017](https://stratechery.com/2017/the-great-unbundling/#:\~:text=tv%20is%20broken%20up%20into%20the%20different%20%E2%80%9Cjobs%E2%80%9D%20it%20has%20traditionally%20done): TV used to keep us **informed**, **educate** us, show **live events**, tell **stories**, and provide **escapism**. But now we get our information from Google; our education from YouTube, Coursera, or Masterworks; our live events from Twitch; our story-telling from Netflix; and our escapism from social media. It’s not as neat as this of course: in reality, everything just exploded into a plethora of mainly mobile options; but unbundling is happening.

[4](#footnote-anchor-4) I number crunched some of the Instagram follower stats [here](https://mention.com/en/reports/instagram/followers/) and would estimate that of all the follower-followee relationships, the largest 1% of accounts receive about 50% of all following relationships.

[5](#footnote-anchor-5) I’m undecided and unclear on what this means for ‘great’ or ‘classic’ cultural contributions. If a great cultural contribution captures an image of society, but also moves it on, how can it be classic, if being classic is continuing to capture that image of society: hasn’t society moved on and been influenced by your contribution? 

[6](#footnote-anchor-6) Woodbury is mainly making the argument that it is specifically “a 20th-century culture centered around white leading men” that is dying, but whilst it’s true that celebrities are becoming more diverse, what’s more important is that they’re becoming less relevant. The social media era is dying; the social community era is coming.

[7](#footnote-anchor-7) It’s ironic that in principle ‘agency’ is the most important thing in the world, whilst ‘agencies’ that help brands and creators reach their fans are typically seen as vultures.

[8](#footnote-anchor-8) I also expect niche and tailored content that is ***emphatically artificial***: a further implication of this, from the unrelated and sufficient cause of AI too, is that individuals will asymptote towards consuming cultural content that is tailored just for them: *an audience of one*. As artificial intelligence (which was also covered [last month](http://The asymptote we reach is that for most people, most of the time, their reading and viewing material is created just for them)) gets more able to accurately predict our interests and preferences at a subtle scale, we get to a world in which content is designed – no, generated – to appeal specifically to us. GPT-3 is an OpenAI algorithm that can conduct incredibly lifelike conversation (at times). [The Next Web](https://thenextweb.com/news/openai-punished-dev-used-gpt-3-to-resurrect-dead-ethics) covers the story of one developer who used the algorithm to sell bots that spoke with the *individual personalities* of an individual chosen by a customer, including dead relatives. As always, there are challenges that accompany change, as well as opportunities; AI will continue to develop, but the risk and threat of AI trained to stimulate and manipulate us need to be managed. *Further reading: [The Diff](https://www.thediff.co/p/what-happens-when-most-media-is-produced?s=r) explores this idea from a more financial perspective; the [NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/03/27/1088140809/fake-linkedin-profiles) illustrates a perfect example, with fake LinkedIn profiles generated explicitly to pique your interest; [Tyler Cowen](https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/04/when-your-bot-is-better-than-you.html) touches on the issue from the other perspective, that of the person using the bot.*

[9](#footnote-anchor-9) Sources: Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube stats [here](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/); in 2021 Spotify paid [$7bn](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) to [8 million](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) creators, which is $875 or £700 (slightly higher than the claim in the a16z source above).

[10](#footnote-anchor-10) Take the price of Bitcoin as a proxy for ‘web3 in vogue’ for a moment. When a16z published the 100 True Fans articles in February 2020, Bitcoin was worth under <$10k, and wouldn’t get above that price until October. The niche market vibe shift predates the cultural significance of web3 and crypto.

[11](#footnote-anchor-11) I’m simplifying a lot; this isn’t a technical introduction to web3. Most obviously, it’s not the case that each person has to manually agree everything in a distributed ledger. Rather, it’s every computer server; and it’s not every computer server, it’s those who proactively commit to contributing to manage the ledger and communicating with it. A good introductory podcast [here](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6N7cIUkh0DnADrJpWlzcY3?si=7rj7ns-AQTqwShJvTHRfOQ); a more detailed introduction [here](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/); a more technical and key whitepaper [here](https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/); and for more depth I suggest the further reading listed under the whitepaper.

[12](#footnote-anchor-12) This illustrates Vitalik Buterin’s (founder of Ethereum) infamous Uber [quote](https://proxet.com/blog/how-the-blockchain-is-changing-money-and-business/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9C-,whereas%20,-most%20%20tend%20%20workers): taxi profiles will be stored on chain, and Uber, Lyft, and more will compete to show you the same drivers, giving the drivers much more power and compensation — which they [need](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_resource_theory). *(There we go, I actually got a politics link in.)*

[13](#footnote-anchor-13) This idea comes from Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit. I don’t think MVC will *replace* MVP - you still need a good product - but your community has to be part of the same conversation.

title: Problem Solving & Storytelling
body:
Some thoughts on why we're so polarized and incapable of constructive dialogue...

Human experience comes down to two things: problem solving and storytelling.

Problem solving is the cybernetic process of communication and control in the pursuit of goals.

Storytelling is the sense-making of our experience as problem solvers through goal-directed behavior.

Cybernetics is the idea that in the pursuit of some goal (docking a boat) we have to constantly adapt to our environment (wind, rain, tide) and adjust course (steer) to achieve that goal.

What we take in and how we react to it is a circular feedback process, and we judge our success by how close or far away we are from our goal. This process operates at every level of life — the goals just shift based on local context and conditions.

At the human level, each of us pursue our own goals and sense-make for ourselves. We individually construct an interpretation of our experience according to our own central nervous system and consciousness.

It’s only in relation to other human beings that we have to contend with the goals of other individuals. And it’s there where shared or competing goals are determined.

Socially, we’re aided by shared languaging (the totality of our intercommunications) and the emergent culture surrounding us, which further scaffolds, frames, and constrains our individual experience of sense-making.

Our personal realities are relative, subject to the localized information available to one’s consciousness in each moment. But through languaging and conversation, we explore our intersubjective experiences of the world together.

Conversation is used to explore potential solutions to perceived problems. If an intersubjective, shared meaning can be established, a foundation for collaborative sense-making and storytelling can be built upon. Agreement might be found.

However, if the “maps of meaning” aren’t agreed upon, the definition of the “problem”, defined as one’s distance from the imagined goal, also can’t be agreed upon and collaborative progress won’t be made.

The conversation will be deemed unproductive and impractical relative to one’s goal and violence will be inevitable.

When each party’s perspective is based on the belief that “facts” exist, independent of observers, it leads to entrenched positions. Reason no longer works.

New “facts” aren't accepted because the framing of those facts is entangled in the subjective scaffolding of the individual and the emergent cultural context they’re embedded within.

The other observer is embedded in a different “reality.” The information of their intersubjective experience is only accessible to them and like-minded others.

Good faith conversation between parties with opposing viewpoints remains our only hope for resolution, but no shared agreement should be expected.

The distance between consciousnesses and their sense-making, the perceived problems to be solved, and the culture that enmeshes these experiences, is too great.

But we have to keep trying.

title: Community and the niche market vibe shift
body:
***Brands and creators that build for niche and dedicated communities will win the 2020s.***

I’ve seen a lot more sweetshops around recently. Specifically, these Victorian-themed tuckshops and sweet connoisseurs, plucked from two hundred years prior and plopped in the middle of a high street that doesn’t quite know how to welcome its new tenant. One of the sweet shops near me plasters ‘Toys, Trains, Treats” on dated storefront panelling; it’s the shop you thought your grandparents went to when they were young, except the steam trains on sale are battery powered.

This wasn’t just a Baader–Meinhof [phenomenon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency_illusion), where upon seeing something once you perceive it everywhere. During the first year of the pandemic, an extra [73](https://www.mylondon.news/news/uk-world-news/i-visited-londons-new-dangerous-22961908#:\~:text=73%20more%20sweet%20shops%20in%20the%20uk%20compared%20with%202020) sweetshops popped up in the UK, net, according to the Local Data Company. That’s not a huge number, but it’s pretty significant given the broader lockdown context; the total number of clothing shops fell by 1,236 in the same period[1](#footnote-1). The shop near me was set up in September ‘21. It begs the question: what’s so special about sweet shops?

I had spent my Saturday morning at Waterstones buying some books, at the sweet shop questioning the shop assistant, and now I’m writing about it on Substack. In days gone by, I would have bought my physical items at Sainsbury’s and, in comparison to today, where I have my Substack and my main [website](https://www.leonasskau.co.uk/), all my digital publishing would be through the same technology stack, probably Wordpress.

Sweets are nice, but the real difference is the existence of a shop that will focus all of its resources on their specific niche product. I bought some weird caramel chocolate flakes that defy description, but they were excellent. I certainly paid a premium, but next time I want sweets, I’ll go there again, because *they know their product*; I just bought what the shop assistant recommended. At Waterstone’s, I picked up [Train Dreams](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/13/train-dreams-denis-johnson-review) because I told the manager I was after contemporary fiction; I use Substack because it’s built for writers[2](#footnote-2). **What makes these businesses special is that they serve *niche markets in which they can give people much deeper value.***

![I mean, you get what I’m saying, despite the weird animojis, right? (HelloDorking)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xRINH9-26W7ZvCggFpXtm.jpeg?height=2438&width=3024)

## Unbundling into niches

Bundling and unbundling are [not new concepts](https://hbr.org/1999/03/unbundling-the-corporation). It’s a pretty simple convection model: you start with a business, over time you add more products, services, and features, and then you get bloated, do everything ‘kinda well’, until a niche competitor comes along and does *one* of your services *really really well*, and bit by bit you get pieced apart. The [complexity convection](https://every.to/divinations/complexity-convection-765851) is a pattern that cannot be unseen. 

People have observed this happening to our contemporary digital landscape for about a decade, beginning in practice much earlier. Craigslist was [unbundled](https://thegongshow.tumblr.com/post/345941486/the-spawn-of-craigslist-like-most-vcs-that-focus) into many things, including Reddit, which is now being [unbundled](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/the-guide-to-unbundling-reddit?s=r) into many more things, like Nextdoor. In the language of [a16z](https://a16z.com/2019/09/11/platforms-verticals-unbundling/), the famed tech investors: platforms get unbundled into verticals, which turn into platforms, at which point the cycle resumes, and all of a sudden I’ve turned into a strategy writer[3](#footnote-3). 

I’m not the first to herald this unbundling in the physical world either. Peter Day [wrote](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=Economy%2C%20%20almost%20a,speed%20and%20efficiency.) an excellent essay predicting “the heartbeat economy, almost a concierge approach to customers,” in 2013:

> `“This would be a worryingly intimate relationship for many businesses, but one which might provide a new kind of rewarding marketplace if they dared to be far closer to their customers' individuality.”`

He wrote about it in the BBC, but today he would write on his own blog.

My real contribution is to note that this challenges why unbundling and bundling happens at all. The main idea behind why we sway between bundled and unbundled products is the [underlying technology](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling#:\~:text=a%20lot%20of%20it%20is%20based%20on%20the%20underlying%20technology%20change). Marc Andreesen, co-founder of a16z and of [Mosaic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_(web_browser)), the first web browser, talks through the concept of the newspaper:

> `“The newspaper bundle, the idea of this slug of news and sports scores and classifieds and stock quotes that arrives once a day was a consequence of the printing plant, of the distribution network for newspapers using trucks and newsstands, and the famous newspaper delivery boy. That newspaper bundle was based on the distribution technology of a time and place.`
>
> `When the distribution technology changed with the internet, there was going to be the great unwind, and then the great rebundle, in the form of Google and Facebook and Twitter.”`

This is certainly true: we could only put [live events on Twitch](https://youtu.be/TCPjk8Tpb5c?t=1025) after network infrastructure made it cheap enough to broadcast live video around the world.

But it’s no coincidence that physical businesses are unbundling at the same time as digital ones, despite relying on different technologies, and often very little tech at all. Neither technology nor innovations built upon it come from magic: what consumers *actually want* plays a key role; today it’s driven by the niche market vibe shift.

Why? Well first, consumer demand fosters technological innovation. I took a cursory glance at solar panels [last month](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/podcast-discussion-negotiating-our?s=w#:\~:text=we%E2%80%99re%20already%20on%20the%20way.%20solar%2C%20wind%2C%20fusion%2C%20geothermal%2C%20and%20hydrogen%20energy%20technologies%20have%20all%20advanced%20significantly%20even%20in%20the%20past%20decade.), where growing consumer demand and growing production have *induced* new technologies; if people hadn’t bothered to use streaming services in the early days, there wouldn’t have been the investment that made them possible at scale. Substack was built because its founders [believed](https://every.to/divinations/substack-s-ideology) writers wanted to offer readers deeper value in a specific niche - and that [readers would pay for it](https://twitter.com/hamishmckenzie/status/1532432557513404416) – not due to any new technologies, just due to the niche market vibe shift.

Second, even when this technological innovation happens, there is no rule commanding consumers to use every new use case that’s suddenly made possible. Google, Facebook, and Twitter all had to create new bundles that people actually wanted to use: do [Google+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google%2B), [Google Answers](http://answers.google.com/answers/faq.html#:\~:text=google%20answers%20was%20an%20experimental%20product%20for%20users%20to%20get%20help%20from%20researchers%20with%20expertise%20in%20online%20searching.), or [Google Notebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Notebook#:\~:text=allowed%20users%20to%20save%20and%20organize%20clips%20of%20information%20while%20conducting%20research%20online) ring a bell?

**I think the reason I’m seeing more sweetshops around is because of a niche market vibe shift. The technology for serving more niche communities has always existed, but now consumers actually want it. *But what does this mean?***


---

I have two quick points before we move on: why this insight is important and why this shift is happening.

First, understanding that bundling and unbundling cycles sway partly due to social preferences, as well as technology, is important to understanding where these sways stop and start, and how to take advantage of them. If it’s true that people want more meaningful, participatory communities, that tells us a lot more about where the future is going than simply observing the entire possibility space opened up by new technologies. When I looked at those failed Google products, I got the impression that Google - founded by Stanford grads - originally sought to be a lot more academic than it is today, with tools for professional research and note-taking. We can understand that these products failed because they weren’t aligned with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, even though they were technically feasible.

Second, my quick take is that this shift has its roots in society’s search for reciprocal connection. The 21st century is probably the only century that will ever be worth calling ‘the internet century’ (by the 22nd the internet won’t be exciting anymore). Today’s internet is very uni-directional, with big influencers megaphoning to their followers[4](#footnote-4). But people also want to [belong ](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/about#:\~:text=the%20sense%20of%20belonging%20that%20humans%20inherently%20desire)to something, and as I wrote a few months ago, building connections *[within](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/leading-movements-communicating-change?s=w#:\~:text=so%20build%20connections-,within,-your%20movement)* your community makes it so much more fulfilling. You feel you’re really participating, and this is really why I go to the sweet shop. Society just invented the internet, and is searching for meaning. Also [G](https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/12/great-recession-still-with-us/547268/).[F](https://www.bruegel.org/2018/10/ten-years-after-the-crisis-the-wests-failure-pushing-china-towards-state-capitalism/).[C](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227439075_THE_IMPACT_OF_THE_ECONOMIC_CRISIS_ON_CULTURE).

![This is a great time to take a break, maybe stretch your legs, and share with a friend! (Kevin Huynh)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7pYdkgZ_QQytonD6G7z0-.webp?height=796&width=1456)


---

The rest of this essay is to explore how this shift is influencing culture. We can think pretty big about *all* the unbundling opportunities new technologies bring: in *[Life After Google](https://www.waterstones.com/book/life-after-google/george-gilder/9781621575764)*, Gilder points out that even money *could* be unbundled, though I don’t think this is on the cards. It’s possible, but consumers don’t actually want to unbundle money into a store of value, unit of account, and so forth. Very few communities are built simply around money as a tool; everyone will *not* become [currency traders](https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/12/11/bitcoin-ethereum-cryptocurrency-web3-great-protocol-politics/#:\~:text=everyone%20becomes%20a%20foreign-exchange%20trader); a niche can’t be built around something that everyone uses, and most people don’t care.

I want to instead focus on culture, which people care a lot about, and is interesting for many further reasons. It interests me how great cultural contributions both capture some image of society whilst also moving it forward[5](#footnote-5). Culture is also beautifully adaptable and flexible and fluid, changing rapidly and exhibiting immense diversity of contribution and consumption: it’s a *collection of niches*. I expect this vibe shift to play out in culture very soon. (It goes without saying that this will occur on the internet.)

That idea of culture as a collection of niches deserves interrogating: culture is also something that we all share. And sure, there will continue to be big Instagram accounts and large supermarkets; shows and books that everyone talks about and events that unite the masses. But as Rex Woodbury notes: “[Celebrities like (Tom) Cruise are a dying breed](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/cultural-transmission-in-the-internet?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NTcwOTkyMTIsIl8iOiJlcTFDOSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDE2NzYxMywiZXhwIjoxNjU0MTcxMjEzLCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzg1MDAiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.pfK8o_nxyz7FIehX7-CkXaRKa-d0-3YhcJ1I1r_YRkg&s=r#:\~:text=celebrities%20like%20cruise%20are%20a%20dying%20breed)”[6](#footnote-6). The 2020s will be defined by the “[long tail of creators](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/the-two-way-mirror-of-art-and-technology?s=w#:\~:text=embolden%20the%20long%20tail%20of%20creators)”, each creating en mass for far smaller communities with much deeper engagement. In the 21st century, we will seek experiences that feel, in some important ways (and not all), totally and emphatically human — that’s why people love [eSports](https://erikhoel.substack.com/p/why-watch-other-people-play-video?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NDUxMzUyMzksIl8iOiJrK0hyQSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDIwNjQ5OSwiZXhwIjoxNjU0MjEwMDk5LCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzMyOTk2Iiwic3ViIjoicG9zdC1yZWFjdGlvbiJ9.T5f6CkyK7SFpzLO3nZZ6U2Zudqkkf4npc9ZsqDnSqFg&s=r#:\~:text=as%20totally%20and%20unabashedly%20human); we’re in the moment *with* the players. **For the hobbies and niches that we love, for which we’re far more than mere followers, we’ll find people serving that niche with dedicated communities built around them.**

[Late Checkout](https://latecheckout.studio/about) is an agency that doesn’t deserve the negative tag associated with such companies[7](#footnote-7); they capture the situation perfectly:

> `“The old way of building products was to try and be everything to everyone. Products were chunky, bloated, and didn’t serve the individual or communities.”`
>
> `“People want to feel a connection to the products they use. They want the internet to feel human and alive again.”`

It’s exciting to see people building the future, and culturally we’re going to see exactly this: **content will be built around niche and dedicated communities with genuine human connection**[8](#footnote-8).


---

## And thus the 1,000 True Fans thesis eventually manifests.

In 2008, Kevin Kelly wrote one of the most seminal contributions in culture tech. The founding editor-in-chief of Wired wrote that, in the internet age:

> `“To make a living as a craftsperson, photographer, musician, designer, author, animator, app maker, entrepreneur, or inventor you need only thousands of true fans.”`

A thousand dedicated fans who love your niche. Sound familiar? 

So what took so long?

It’s certainly the case that the technology of the era made this difficult. Kelly hoped that the internet would be the ultimate matchmaker. Bring the creators and the consumers online, and they will find each other. To an extent, they did, especially in the early days of the internet: in 2008, writing about 1000 True Fans looked sensible. But it was still pretty hard: you could publish your own content, but without mass-market services like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, that helped you discover, it was tough to find or be found.

The introduction of these services, monoliths to be, helped in one sense: it was a lot easier for people to find you on the internet. But the price for this matchmaking was almost everything: Facebook and Instagram take almost 100% of all the revenue creators see on their platforms; YouTube takes 45%; Spotify paid an average of merely £700 to each artist last year[9](#footnote-9). These monoliths do the matching, but make it virtually unaffordable to create in the first place.

It was a vibe shift, not a technological one, that struck the first blow to this impoverished paradigm. Twitch, Kickstarter, Patreon, Substack, amongst many others, are all services built for creators to cater for the dedicated fans of their niche; all built amidst the community-centric vibe shift born in the 2010s. Well before the 2020 crypto bull run, a16z heralded a [100 True Fans model](https://future.a16z.com/1000-true-fans-try-100/) in 2020[10](#footnote-10), arguing that this was made possible with even more niche services from Podia, Teachable, and Kajabi. (These companies *all* help people sell educational courses, which undermines the argument to an extent, but you only need 250 fans paying £20/$25 per month to earn \~3x the average UK salary or [$75,000](https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2019628,00.html#:\~:text=no%20matter%20how%20much%20more), so you get the picture.) **With the alignment of technology and the vibe, the impoverished paradigm of community-stricken creatorship is collapsing.**


---

### Blockchain is a game-changer for this dynamic

*You’re reading on Mirror, so you probably know all this; you could easily skip to the next phrase in bold.*

In the early 2020s, new technologies like blockchain, distributed ledgers, and cryptocurrencies really came in vogue. A distributed ledger is triple-entry bookkeeping. [Double-entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-entry_bookkeeping) bookkeeping was invented in medieval Italy: two parties to a transaction would both record it, giving you more data about your business and more verifiable figures, making it easier to trade and pursue enterprise.

Eight centuries later, distributed ledgers are triple-entry bookkeeping: as well as the seller and buyer, *every participant in the economy* makes a record of the transaction, and every participant is using the same, enormous, book. Blockchain is the technology of how you add to this book and run software with it, and cryptocurrency is one use case: the ledger essentially records how much currency you own, which everyone verifies. Obviously I’m simplifying, but I’ll refer to these technologies as ‘web3 techs’[11](#footnote-11).

The significance of blockchain becomes clear upon interrogating why Facebook, YouTube, *et al.* can take such high take rates on creators. One side is [discovery](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/infinite-scroll/what-the-creator-economy-promises-and-what-it-actually-does#:\~:text=no%20one%20finds%20a%20person%20on%20patreon%3B%20you%20go%20there%20after%20you%E2%80%99ve%20found%20them): you rarely *find* creators on Patreon. This happens, still, on big social networks. Everyone is on these platforms (well, not Facebook) and when you consume on these platforms frequently, they’re experts in figuring out what content you’ll click on next; big data, [Markov chains](https://towardsdatascience.com/introduction-to-markov-chains-50da3645a50d#:\~:text=predict%20weather%20for%20days%20to%20come%2C%20based%20on%20what%20the%20current%20weather%20state%20is%20at%20the%20time), etc. There are some problems with this, mainly that you get served addictive content rather than niches that you want to engage deeply in, but generally they do this job pretty well, and web3 techs don’t hugely change this.

But there are a lot of platforms for discovery — this isn’t the competitive moat it once was. People use Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, Pinterest, and much more, in addition to the discovery platforms we’ve called out above; as mentioned, most people have moved beyond Facebook. Creators could just move to whichever discovery network takes the smallest cut of their revenue. Apart from one thing: they can’t. Everything you’ve ever uploaded to Spotify and all the followers you’ve earnt on Insta: the discovery platform manages this, and you can’t take your community with you. So it’s impossible to leave without starting all over again. And hence discovery networks [squeeze](https://stratechery.com/2015/niches-problem-subscription-services/) creators for revenue.

And hence, the game-changer. Because just like with your cryptocurrency, you can store your [writing](https://mirror.xyz/), your [music](https://sound.xyz/), your [art](https://opensea.io/), your [videos](https://d.tube/), your [followers](https://lens.xyz/), on a distributed ledger, or “on chain”. As [LBRY](https://lbry.io/) puts it: “LBRY does to publishing what Bitcoin did to money.” Just like with your currency, everyone participating in the economy agrees that “yes, [Leo](https://app.ens.domains/name/leosn.eth/details), you wrote this blog”. Sites like Spotify and Instagram don’t manage your songs and your followers because these songs and follower relationships are stored on chain, and Spotify is reduced to one of many organisations competing to merely display this content in the best way, and help you discover new content as well. Creators are not beholden to any of them – and neither are consumers[12](#footnote-12).

So now the community economy is fully on the way because finally, **dedicated participants in a niche community can meaningfully support their creators**. When people are deeply engaged in something they care about, even the original consumers become contributors, and we’ll start to see vibrant ecosystems formed around niches and creators. Greg Isenberg explores the [Loot ecosystem](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/heres-what-the-future-of-nfts-looks?s=r#:\~:text=it%E2%80%99s%20an%20ecosystem%20not%20just%20an%20nft), an NFT project upon which creators have realised myriad different ideas; [Jenkins the Valet](https://www.jenkinsthevalet.com/how-it-works) is a great example of community-led storytelling, which will become a category-defining cultural genre in the 2020s, on par with ‘art’ and ‘literature’. [Jadyn Violet](https://twitter.com/jadynviolet), a musician, told me that “I’ve never got this much interaction on my art before.” He's been spending his time building new ideas to engage his community, spending time speaking with his fans, and making more music — this is what his fans love him for.

Business people often talk about the Minimum Viable Product your business needs before you start selling. The MVP isn’t dead, but all businesses (not just creators) will soon require a [Minimum Viable Community](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uPRruLfZoU&t=2s) to make a mark in their market[13](#footnote-13).

What will underlie all of these communities are tokens of membership, probably tiered, which tie a community together. They’ll be non-fungible, which means they’ll be unique and personalisable, thus allowing for deeper engagement. **Consumers get dedicated community and deeper value in a niche they care about; creators are finally rewarded fairly for their work.** 

![Tiered NFT collections can help creators build more intimate communities. Everyone wants this; web3 makes it possible. (Peter Yang)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OjR9B7mzwKA76xALqr8qk.png?height=512&width=1167)

## An exciting future, not an Exciting one

In 1999, Excite was a $6.7bn search engine, but collapsed soon after the 2001 dotcom crash. Google was only just getting started, but after aligning with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, became the favoured search engine of billions.

Joe Kraus, the founder of Excite, [explains why](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=i%20went%20to%20revisit%20joe%20kraus): Excite had been a 20th century company, targeting revenue from the top ten American companies, as media businesses had been doing for decades. Meanwhile, Google focused on attracting advertisers — and millions of them. Why did this work? *“The 20th century was about dozens of markets of millions of consumers. **The 21st century is about millions of markets of dozens of consumers.**”*


---

*Hopefully that didn’t actually feel like 3,000 words; I’d love it if you were to [subscribe](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/subscribe) for free or mint one of 5 editions.*


---

`Image credits: HelloDorking; Kevin Huynh; Peter Yang`

***Footnotes:***

*Mirror doesn’t do footnote links well yet, but I couldn’t bear to publish without them.*

[1](#footnote-anchor-1) I don’t have the percentage figures for the change in sweetshops and clothing stores, I’m sorry.

[2](#footnote-anchor-2) Other blogging platforms are available, including this one, but they’re still *built* for writers; I’m testing the beta of [Nuance](http://nuance.xyz/).

[3](#footnote-anchor-3) Stratechery anticipated this for (cable) TV in [2013](https://stratechery.com/2013/the-jobs-tv-does/#:\~:text=the%20jobs%20tv%20has%20traditionally%20done%20include) and watched it happen in [2017](https://stratechery.com/2017/the-great-unbundling/#:\~:text=tv%20is%20broken%20up%20into%20the%20different%20%E2%80%9Cjobs%E2%80%9D%20it%20has%20traditionally%20done): TV used to keep us **informed**, **educate** us, show **live events**, tell **stories**, and provide **escapism**. But now we get our information from Google; our education from YouTube, Coursera, or Masterworks; our live events from Twitch; our story-telling from Netflix; and our escapism from social media. It’s not as neat as this of course: in reality, everything just exploded into a plethora of mainly mobile options; but unbundling is happening.

[4](#footnote-anchor-4) I number crunched some of the Instagram follower stats [here](https://mention.com/en/reports/instagram/followers/) and would estimate that of all the follower-followee relationships, the largest 1% of accounts receive about 50% of all following relationships.

[5](#footnote-anchor-5) I’m undecided and unclear on what this means for ‘great’ or ‘classic’ cultural contributions. If a great cultural contribution captures an image of society, but also moves it on, how can it be classic, if being classic is continuing to capture that image of society: hasn’t society moved on and been influenced by your contribution? 

[6](#footnote-anchor-6) Woodbury is mainly making the argument that it is specifically “a 20th-century culture centered around white leading men” that is dying, but whilst it’s true that celebrities are becoming more diverse, what’s more important is that they’re becoming less relevant. The social media era is dying; the social community era is coming.

[7](#footnote-anchor-7) It’s ironic that in principle ‘agency’ is the most important thing in the world, whilst ‘agencies’ that help brands and creators reach their fans are typically seen as vultures.

[8](#footnote-anchor-8) I also expect niche and tailored content that is ***emphatically artificial***: a further implication of this, from the unrelated and sufficient cause of AI too, is that individuals will asymptote towards consuming cultural content that is tailored just for them: *an audience of one*. As artificial intelligence (which was also covered [last month](http://The asymptote we reach is that for most people, most of the time, their reading and viewing material is created just for them)) gets more able to accurately predict our interests and preferences at a subtle scale, we get to a world in which content is designed – no, generated – to appeal specifically to us. GPT-3 is an OpenAI algorithm that can conduct incredibly lifelike conversation (at times). [The Next Web](https://thenextweb.com/news/openai-punished-dev-used-gpt-3-to-resurrect-dead-ethics) covers the story of one developer who used the algorithm to sell bots that spoke with the *individual personalities* of an individual chosen by a customer, including dead relatives. As always, there are challenges that accompany change, as well as opportunities; AI will continue to develop, but the risk and threat of AI trained to stimulate and manipulate us need to be managed. *Further reading: [The Diff](https://www.thediff.co/p/what-happens-when-most-media-is-produced?s=r) explores this idea from a more financial perspective; the [NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/03/27/1088140809/fake-linkedin-profiles) illustrates a perfect example, with fake LinkedIn profiles generated explicitly to pique your interest; [Tyler Cowen](https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/04/when-your-bot-is-better-than-you.html) touches on the issue from the other perspective, that of the person using the bot.*

[9](#footnote-anchor-9) Sources: Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube stats [here](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/); in 2021 Spotify paid [$7bn](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) to [8 million](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) creators, which is $875 or £700 (slightly higher than the claim in the a16z source above).

[10](#footnote-anchor-10) Take the price of Bitcoin as a proxy for ‘web3 in vogue’ for a moment. When a16z published the 100 True Fans articles in February 2020, Bitcoin was worth under <$10k, and wouldn’t get above that price until October. The niche market vibe shift predates the cultural significance of web3 and crypto.

[11](#footnote-anchor-11) I’m simplifying a lot; this isn’t a technical introduction to web3. Most obviously, it’s not the case that each person has to manually agree everything in a distributed ledger. Rather, it’s every computer server; and it’s not every computer server, it’s those who proactively commit to contributing to manage the ledger and communicating with it. A good introductory podcast [here](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6N7cIUkh0DnADrJpWlzcY3?si=7rj7ns-AQTqwShJvTHRfOQ); a more detailed introduction [here](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/); a more technical and key whitepaper [here](https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/); and for more depth I suggest the further reading listed under the whitepaper.

[12](#footnote-anchor-12) This illustrates Vitalik Buterin’s (founder of Ethereum) infamous Uber [quote](https://proxet.com/blog/how-the-blockchain-is-changing-money-and-business/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9C-,whereas%20,-most%20%20tend%20%20workers): taxi profiles will be stored on chain, and Uber, Lyft, and more will compete to show you the same drivers, giving the drivers much more power and compensation — which they [need](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_resource_theory). *(There we go, I actually got a politics link in.)*

[13](#footnote-anchor-13) This idea comes from Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit. I don’t think MVC will *replace* MVP - you still need a good product - but your community has to be part of the same conversation.

title: Will P2E NFTs evolve into overpriced loot boxes?
body:
## Long story short, yes, or rather maybe…

Yes I know that is as vague as it can be, but let’s try to untangle the non-existing regulation around NFTs and what some recent development in European legislation could mean to the emerging market of NFTs.

We need to consider two things:

* Are pre-reveal PFP and P2E NFTs loot boxes?
* If yes, would the loot box legislation apply to them?

### So can we consider NFTs as loot boxes?

We can and we should.

> Loot boxes are a feature within video games that allow players to partake in a game of chance, exchanging real world money for a randomised in-game item or benefit.

In this definition our pre-reveal NFTs could be considered randomized in-game items, especially if they are part of a P2E game, given their attributes are randomly generated from legendary 1/1s to uncommon 10000/1s, which would also constitute a game of chance aspect. Can we say that we can exchange these P2E NFTs for real-world money? Of course, even if the P2E game uses a niche crypto token to purchase these NFTs, we still can exchange our tokens for cash on any CEX and vice-versa.

### So would the loot box apply to the NFT market?

Probably would change how we reveal NFTs, but the market as a whole won’t be regulated anytime soon.

The most recent addition to the not-so-long list of loot box-related regulations comes as consumer groups in 18 European countries jointly announced that they will launch a coordinated call to action to pass regulations on the despicable practices around loot boxes. The 59=page long report details key issues with loot boxes and their mechanism, a few for the sake of understanding the issue:

* Exploiting cognitive biases and vulnerabilities through deceptive design
* Using aggressive marketing practices to push sales at every opportunity
* Using layers of virtual currencies to mask or distort real-world monetary costs

Even before the years of the pandemic-induced chaos around the world, legislators tried to look into the issue at hand, most notably in Belgium where EA had to stop selling FIFA points, and in the Netherlands, the company was fined 500,000€ each week they continued selling loot boxes in their games (this decision has been since ruled as unjustified). Following the BENELUX success, the UK government also started a multi-year investigation on whether they could change the gambling legislation to regulate loot boxes accordingly. This was recently published as an overview by the House of Commons Library;

* In September 2019, a House of Commons Committee published a report on technologies that called for regulations to be made to extend the 2005 Act to loot boxes.
* In June 2020, the Government announced that it would be launching a call for evidence into the impact of loot boxes on gambling-like behavior.
* A July 2020 House of Lords Committee report on gambling harm also called for loot boxes to be brought within the scope of the Act.
* On 19 May 2022, the Government said a gambling white paper would be published in the “coming weeks”.

If we look at these common issues with loot box mechanisms in the video games industry we can see why they would apply to the current P2E market. Imagine a virtual world where you earn or buy virtual tokens that you can exchange for in-game characters or features, this would be per definition the loot box mechanism that the legislators are trying to regulate to keep children safe. In this regards the general PFP market might also fall into this category.

### What can we do about it?

While the legislators are working on actually taking care of this problem that is now part of most video games, the NFT market should self-regulate and try to come up with a better solution for pre-reveal PFP NFTs and purchasable P2E NFTs.

Do I have a solution? No.

Do I believe in NFT technology? Yes.

title: Giới Thiệu về Pre-Crime
body:
tldr: ngăn chặn những vụ hack trước khi chúng xảy ra

Hiện nay, việc những hệ thống cầu nối bị tấn công diễn ra khá thường xuyên với tổn thất ngày càng gia tăng. Đa số những vụ tấn công này liên quan đến hợp đồng thông minh thay vì nền tảng vận chuyển. Tuy nhiên các lớp trung gian này vẫn giáng đòn cuối cùng bởi chúng giúp gửi đi những thông điệp để hoàn thành những vụ tấn công tài chính. Vậy nếu chúng ta có thể ngăn chặn cái bước cuối cùng đó thì sao?

LayerZero ra mắt Pre-Crime, chức năng giúp một lớp vận chuyển ngăn chặn vụ tấn công trước khi nó diễn ra. Pre-Crime đạt được bằng cách phân nhánh blockchain đích trước khi gửi một tin nhắn và chạy giao dịch cục bộ. Sau khi xử lý giao dịch, Pre-Crime có thể kiểm tra tình trạng của blockchain với những blockchain liên quan để xác nhận rằng không có hoạt động đáng nghi nào diễn ra. Những tình huống độc hại này được xác định bởi User Application (UA) và thực thi bởi lớp vận chuyển.

Pre-Crime cung cấp cho các UA một lớp bảo mật bổ sung bên cạnh việc kiểm toán và các chương trình săn lỗi bảo mật. Những người chuyển tiếp bây giờ có thể chạy một tập xác nhận do UA định nghĩa trên một blockchain phân nhánh nội bộ để xác nhận từng tin nhắn gửi đi không dẫn đến một tình trạng nguy hại. Nếu như việc xác nhận thất bại thì tầng trung gian sẽ không gửi đi thông điệp, ngăn chặn được vụ tấn công và bảo vệ UA khỏi tai hoạ.

Hãy tưởng tượng một phương thức cầu nối truyền thống được triển khai trên LayerZero thông qua việc khoá tài sản trên chuỗi nguồn và đào một tài sản chuyển đổi tương ứng trên chuỗi đích. Giao dịch cầu nối này kích hoạt chức năng xác nhận trước vi phạm bằng một tập điều kiện bắt buộc phải thông qua trước khi được phê duyệt. Một trong những điều kiện đấy là khả năng thanh toán của cầu nối giúp đảm bảo rằng khoản đặt cọc và tài sản khoá phải bằng giá trị với những tài sản chuyển đổi.

Đáng tiếc là phương thức cầu nối này có một lỗ hổng trong mã nguồn đã cho phép những kẻ lợi dụng tạo ra thông điệp giả và khai thác tài sản trên chuỗi đích mà không cung cấp đủ tài sản thế chấp trên chuỗi nguồn. Khi tin nhắn này được gửi đi, tầng trung gian chạy giao dịch cục bộ, phát hiện ra điều kiện về khả năng thanh toán không hợp lệ và ngăn chặn tội ác trước khi nó diễn ra.

Pre-Crime chỉ là một trong nhiều bước mà LayerZero thực hiện để đảm bảo tính bảo mật cho tương lai của chuỗi chéo. Hiện tại thì tầng vận chuyển của LayerZero Labs đang chạy phiên bản nhẹ của Pre-Crime và sẽ hoàn thiện chức năng này trong những tháng tới. Trong tương lai, Pre-Crime sẽ được ra mắt cho toàn bộ các ứng dụng người dùng muốn tham gia vào việc bảo vệ dự án của mình.

title: HASH DAO ($HASH) Whitepaper
body:
*Updated : May 2022*

**Mission : Our mission is to cultivate Web3 community horticulture for the future of the cannabis space.** 

HASH DAO provides the first unified DAO solution for craft cannabis farmers, industry professionals, investors, and BIPOC communities interested in the cannabis space.

HASH DAO has been created to allow integration into the emerging technologies of the blockchain and Web3 into the cannabis space. Focusing on farmers who put the plant first and under represented communities. To do this, we start by partnering with Uncle Mac's brand to create the world’s first Web3 Cannabis brand and community tooling of horticulture. Building a growing compilation of automation protocols using smart contracts, HASH DAO Governance seeks to be the future industry standard.

**Problem : Removing the Gatekeepers to Funding Craft Cannabis Operators**

*“Decades of marijuana prohibition and high incarceration rates for marijuana convictions has left many people out of the legal marijuana boom.”*

> **Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space**

The multi-billion dollar cannabis industry is entering it’s boom phase as more global cannabis markets arise and support for [U.S. federal legalization](https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3617) continues to grow support, in 2020 alone the cannabis space grew to over $20 Billion and is projected to 10x in the next decade.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

Corporate cannabis companies operate and control the majority of the space, leaving legacy operators and small brands without capital solutions to scale their businesses and do not take into consideration all of it’s stakeholders :

* The Growers & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oXXVXLuIXOQoXtXRqzBXV.png?height=621&width=904)

The majority of the craft cannabis space, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the patient, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly fined small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in and often don’t receive proper credit. Certain strains go on to become cultural identities that generate massive value, I.E. the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

**HIGHLIGHT FRESH FROZEN PROBLEM**

![Exclusive Libraries of Genetics & Phenos](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-8T4OrLTcNOJxW2vLerl-.jpg?height=1866&width=1536)

*Solution?* Highly Autonomous Systems of Horticulture (**$HASH**) : Utilizing smart contracts to automate and democratize production, supply chain, and governance in the cannabis & psychedelic industry.

Creating community-ownership of the vertically-integrated $HASH Supply Chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis  compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. Information, data security, and their applications are essential for business optimization and transparency. Although there are many ERP solutions for the industry already, our governance will be centered around cannabis supply chain and DeFi dApps that utilize NFT-based SKU’s to generate active product data and create on-chain interactions that comply with ESG metrics, paving the way for global regulations and the future of the cannabis space.

Developing Horticulture Public Goods : BIPOC Horticulture Initiative, Open-Source Library of Genetics, Strains and Phenos, Regenerative Farming Methods & Techniques, Cannabis Production, Processing, Entheogenic Cultivation, Medicinal Protocols, and a Community-Practitioner Directory

Community-Governance over the liquidity, yield-farming, and major-user decisions in the tokenization of HASH DAO. 

**DERO Data Privacy** **+ Tokenization of Security**

HASH DAO Governance is the future of the industry standard, and to do this we will start by partnering with one successful Emerald Triangle, Northern California craft cannabis-brand with community-staking of its future scaling of operations and expanding a compilation of automation protocols through smart contracts.

**ON-CHAIN SUPPLY NFTs + ACTIVE INVENTORY TRACKING + CRYPTO TRANSACTIONS = Web3 Point of Sale (PoS)**

**World’s First Cannabis DAO Founded On**:

BIPOC-equity and engineered around community-development governed by craft cannabis operators, backed by IRL projects.

**On-Chain Protocols + Smart Contracts = The Automated Horticulture of Tomorrow**

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding BIPOC leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

> **HASH DAO = Power Back in Your Hands**

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/M6C2p0sNHx37p783TEv9D.jpg?height=822&width=1125)

**First Wins for HASH DAO**

> “Community Ownership of Physical and Digital Assets”

Minting a multi-tiered HASH DAO NFT with the top governance tier going for $10 K, raising a total of $11.5 M for an initial $HASH treasury. As funds become available, proceeds will immediately go to partnering with South Face Mangement to purchase over 30 acres in Mendocino and 40+ acres Humbolt County. This will include the scaling of a vertically-integrated nursery, farm, hash processing, and soon-to-launch retail of award-winning legacy products under Uncle Mac’s brand and South Face Farms Management.

**Project #1 :**  Carry out renovation on the farm and nursery to ensure full-scale ESG-metric compliance and how to bring all aspects of the farm and it’s production on-chain, from SKU NFT’s to utilizing energy consumption data for carbon credit checks. Partnering with Uncle Mac’s, a Northern California craft cannabis brand, & South Face Management, parent company to Flower Wheel Nursery, South Face Farms Cultivation, and Uncle Mac’s brand.

**Project #2 :** Onboard visual and 3D artists who will design branding and assets for the Metaverse and we develop cross-chain NFT’s to be dropped on various play-to-earn games. We will also be acquiring digital plots of real estate to build “Metaverse farms” and “digital dispensaries” where a user can view the product, find out all of it’s information, and have it eventually delivered through an on-chain transaction. Along with digital land we will also be investing in domain names, including various strain names, cannabis celebrities, and psychedelic culture. Explore liquidity pools and yield farming with assets and treasury.

**Project #3 :** For the third project, we’ll be launching Uncle Mac's HASH House is an Emerald Triangle legacy project. This on-chain Hash House is the home lab for Uncle Mac’s production. We will also operate as a wholesale fresh frozen supply chain solution for transportation, storage, distribution and hash toll processing throughout the greater Emerald Triangle area.

**Project #4** : Getting $HASH in your hands. This is our farm-to-table craft cannabis buyers club providing direct-to-consumer access to exclusive SKU’s from legacy brands in the Emerald Triangle. This will include obtaining a retail and event license to launch Nephew’s Automated.

**Project #5 :** Aggregating a library of horticulture public goods & building the Biodiversity BIPOC Glamping Learning Initiative; start building Marijuana for Minorities Program to co-create $HASH University creating content with some of the best small-batch growers and washers in the industry. (Community Online Education)

**Project #6 :** Nephew’s will be applying for its event space license building the foundation for Akasha, an immersive psychedelic A/R Lounge for BIPOC community healing. The distribution and delivery will be a warehouse that will have an on-chain ESG-metric system in the back and a public access immersive art space in the front. We will also be looking into developing a portfolio of boutique cannabis bud and breakfasts in emerging global cannabis markets.

**Project #7 :** We will be finding ERP solutions to develop state-of-the-art horticulture automation and Web3 technologies, based upon on-chain governance and compliance, to pave the way for the international industry standard by working towards meeting ESG-metric compliance. Our final goal is developing complete automation systems without compromising craft horticulture. From driverless deliveries, farm drone surveillance & data collection to utilize machine-learning and AI and to understand buyer behavior, horticulture improvements, growth optimization, etc.

body:
*Updated : May 2022*
